As part of the compromise legislation that passed, the tax is also imposed on artificially sweetened beverages, such as diet soda. The law became effective on 1 January 2017.<ref name=Nadolny>{{cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/20160617_Philadelphia_City_Council_to_vote_on_soda_tax.html |title=Soda tax passes; Philadelphia is first big city in nation to enact one |first=Tricia L. |last=Nadolny |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> It was reported after two months of the tax that Philadelphia supermarkets and beverage distributors are planning layoffs because sugary beverage sales are down between 30 and 50 percent.<ref name="Seattle">{{cite news|url=http://www.king5.com/news/local/seattle/seattles-soda-tax-propsal-what-it-will-cost-you/411871456|title= Seattle's soda tax has two goals|publisher=King5|date=February 22, 2017|accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
After the tax took effect, Kenney said it was "wrong" and "misleading" for businesses to pass the tax on to their customers in the form of higher soda prices.<ref>[http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/01/10/retailers-blame-soda-tax-mayor-kenney-responds-with-harsh-words/ Retailers Blame Soda Tax; Mayor Kenney Responds With Harsh Words], CBS News Philadelphia, January 10, 2017</ref> In February 2017, soda manufacturers and retailers announced sales declines of 30-50% in Philadelphia and announced job cuts and layoffs. Kenny characterized the layoffs as evidence of greed among manufacturers.<ref>Julia Terruso (2017). "[http://www.philly.com/philly/news/Soda-companies-supermarkets-report-50-percent-losses-from-soda-tax.html Soda companies, supermarkets report 30-50 pct. sales drop from soda tax]" Philly.com, 21 Feb 2017.</ref> In the first four months of the soda tax $25.6 million was collected, which is lower than predicted.<ref>[http://www.philly.com/philly/news/city-soda-tax-revenue-to-fall-short-20170613.html Philly: Soda tax revenue to fall short] Philly.com, June 13, 2017</ref> The revenue is intended to pay for a pre-K program (49% of tax revenue), government employee benefits and city programs (20%), and rebuilding city parks and recreation centers.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://taxfoundation.org/philadelphia-soda-tax-failing | title = Soda Tax Revenues Lag from Higher Prices, Fewer Purchases, Tax Avoidance | date = August 3, 2017}}</ref> A recent study from 2017 found that Philadelphia's tax has decreased sugary beverage consumption in impoverished youth by 1.3 drinks/week.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Langellier|first=Brent A.|last2=Lê-Scherban|first2=Félice|last3=Purtle|first3=Jonathan|date=8/4/2017|title=Funding quality pre-kindergarten slots with Philadelphia’s new ‘sugary drink tax’: simulating effects of using an excise tax to address a social determinant of health|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/public-health-nutrition/article/funding-quality-prekindergarten-slots-with-philadelphias-new-sugary-drink-tax-simulating-effects-of-using-an-excise-tax-to-address-a-social-determinant-of-health/2D782D726C893556452309434A381ACB|journal=Public Health Nutrition|volume=20|issue=13|pages=2450–2458|doi=10.1017/S1368980017001756|issn=1368-9800|via=}}</ref> Langellier et al. also found that when paired with the pre-K program, attendance increases significantly, a finding that is likely to have longer term positive effects than a sugary drink tax alone.<ref name=":2" />
In March 2017, Pepsi laid off between 80 and 100 employees at two distribution plants in Philadelphia and one plant in nearby [[Wilmington, Delaware]]. The company blamed the layoffs on the tax, an assertion rejected by the city government.<ref>[http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/Pepsi-announces-80-100-layoffs-blames-soda-tax.html Pepsi to lay off 80 to 100, blames soda tax], ''The Philadelphia Inquirer'', March 1, 2017.</ref>
In September 2016, the American Beverage Association, Philadelphia business owners, and other plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the soda tax, alleging that the tax violated the "Tax Uniformity Clause" of the [[Pennsylvania Constitution|state constitution]].<ref>Fabiola Cineas, [http://www.phillymag.com/business/2017/04/05/philadelphia-soda-tax-lawsuit-court/ Philly’s Soda Tax Is Back in Court Today], ''Philadelphia Magazine'' (April 5, 2017).</ref><ref name="Sasko"/> The legal challenge was dismissed by the [[Pennsylvania courts of common pleas|Court of Common Pleas]] in December 2016, and in June 2017 the [[Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania]] (in a 5-2 decision) affirmed that ruling. The ABA is appealing the decision to the [[Pennsylvania Supreme Court]].<ref>[https://billypenn.com/2017/06/14/pennsylvania-commonwealth-court-upholds-philly-soda-tax/ Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court upholds Philly soda tax] Billypenn.com, Retrieved June 23, 2107.</ref><ref>Julia Terruso, [http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/city/beverage-tax-upheld-by-commonwealth-court-20170614.html Beverage tax upheld by Commonwealth Court], ''The Philadelphia Inquirer'' June 14, 2017</ref>
=====San Francisco, California ===== A one-cent-per-ounce soda tax (Prop V) passed with over 61% of the vote on 8 November 2016 and applies to distributors of sugary beverages on 1 January 2018.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/soda-taxes-approved-in-four-cities-vote-looms-in-chicagos-cook-county-1478698979|title=Soda Taxes Approved in Four Cities, Vote Looms in Chicago’s Cook County|first=Mike|last=Esterl|date=9 November 2016|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Exemptions for the tax include infant formulas, milk products, supplements, drinks used for medical reasons, and 100% fruit and vegetable juices.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sugary Drinks Tax Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://sftreasurer.org/sugary-drinks-tax-frequently-asked-questions-faq|website=SF Treasurer|publisher=City and County of San Francisco|accessdate=30 October 2017}}</ref> The soda industry spent almost $20 million in its unsuccessful push to defeat the soda tax initiative, a record-breaking amount for a San Francisco ballot initiative.<ref name="KnightSF2016">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/Record-spending-by-soda-industry-to-defeat-Prop-V-10306250.php/ | work=San Francisco Chronicle | title= Record spending by soda industry to defeat Prop V| first=Heather | last=Knight | date=25 October 2016}}</ref>
In 2014, the first referendum on a soda tax, Proposition E, was voted down by San Francisco; the 2014 referendum received the support of 55 percent of voters, short of the two-thirds required for a referendum directing money to a specific item (the referendum proposed directing the revenue raised to children's physical education and nutrition programs, and in San Francisco such earmarking requires a two-thirds vote to pass).<ref>Heather Knight, [http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Why-Berkeley-passed-a-soda-tax-and-S-F-didn-t-5879757.php Why Berkeley passed a soda tax and S.F. didn't], ''San Francisco Chronicle'' (7 November 2014).</ref> In that referendum campaign, the soda industry spent about $10 million in opposition to the proposed tax.<ref name="KnightSF2016"/>
=====Oakland, California ===== A one-cent-per-ounce soda tax (Measure HH) passed with over 60% of the vote on 8 November 2016. The tax went into effect on 1 July 2017.<ref name="auto"/>
=====Albany, California===== A one-cent-per-ounce soda tax (Prop O1) passed with over 70% of the vote on 8 November 2016.<ref name="auto"/> The tax went into effect on April 1, 2017<ref>City of Albany. [http://38.106.4.142/Modules/ShowDocument.aspx?documentid=29304 "Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Tax FAQs."] </ref>
=====Boulder, Colorado===== A two-cents-per-ounce soda tax (Measure 2H) passed with 54% of the vote on 8 November 2016.<ref name="auto"/> The tax took effect on July 1, 2017, and revenue will be spent on health promotion, general wellness programs and chronic disease prevention that improve health equity, and other health programs especially for residents with low income and those most affected by chronic disease linked to sugary drink consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bouldercolorado.gov/tax-license/finance-sugar-sweetened-beverage-tax|title=Sugar Sweetened Beverage Tax|website=bouldercolorado.gov|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> The tax is exempted at the University of Colorado, Boulder, campus as school officials survey what types of drinks students wish to have. The University was not aware it would be involved in the soda tax, and would have to pay as much as $1 million a year to purchase it.<ref>{{cite news|title=NewsColorado News University of Colorado Boulder receives soda-tax exemption|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/05/23/university-colorado-boulder-soda-tax/|accessdate=24 October 2017|publisher=The Denver Post}}</ref>
=====Cook County, Illinois===== A one-cent-per-ounce soda tax passed on November 10, 2016, by a 9-8 vote, with [[Cook County Board of Commissioners]] President [[Toni Preckwinkle]] breaking the 8-8 tie. [[Cook County]] includes [[Chicago]] and has a population of nearly 5.2 million. This was the most populous jurisdiction with a soda tax in the U.S.<ref>Hal Dardick, [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-cook-county-soda-pop-tax-vote-met-1111-20161110-story.html Cook County soda pop tax approved with Preckwinkle breaking tie vote], ''Chicago Tribune'' (10 November 2016).</ref> The campaign to introduce the tax was heavily funded by [[Mike Bloomberg]].<ref name="veconomist" />
On June 30, 2017, a Cook County judge granted a temporary restraining order filed by the Illinois Retail Merchants Association and several Cook County-based grocers that prohibited the tax from being put into effect until at least July 12.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Channick|first1=Becky Yerak, Robert|title=Judge blocks Cook County soda pop tax|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-cook-soda-tax-0701-biz-20170630-story.html|work=chicagotribune.com}}</ref> The tax eventually went into effect on August 2. Due to a conflict with the [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program]], this soda tax did not apply to any soda purchases made with food stamps, which were used by over 870,000 people.<ref name="veconomist" /><ref>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-cook-county-settles-soda-pop-tax-food-stamp-issues-0818-biz-20170817-story.html Cook County: Soda tax no longer runs afoul of food stamp rules] ''Chicago Tribune'', August 17, 2017.</ref> Controversially, the tax affected diet drinks but not sugar-packed fruit juices.<ref name="veconomist" />
On October 10, 2017, the Board of Commissioners voted to repeal the tax in a 15-1 vote. The tax stayed in effect up until December 1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abc7chicago.com/politics/cook-county-officials-vote-15-1-to-repeal-sugary-drink-tax/2515951/|title=Cook County officials vote 15-1 to repeal sugary drink tax|last=Pathieu|first=Diane|date=2017-10-10|work=ABC7 Chicago|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> The tax was highly unpopular and seen mainly as an attempt to plug the county’s $1.8 billion budget deficit, rather than a public health measure.<ref name="veconomist" >{{cite news|author=V.v.B|title=Chicago’s soda tax is repealed|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/10/fizzled-0|work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 October 2017}}</ref>
=====Portland, Oregon===== The Coalition for Healthy Kids and Education is currently campaigning to get a soda tax on the May 2018 ballot. Their aim is to implement a 1.15 cents per ounce tax on sugary drinks. There are 18,000 signatures required by December 15, 2017 in order for the tax to be voted on in May.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rafanelli|first1=Rachael|title=Soda tax in Multnomah County? Group working to get measure on 2018 ballot|url=http://www.kgw.com/news/group-gathers-signatures-for-proposed-multnomah-county-soda-tax/475549205|accessdate=30 October 2017|agency=KGW|date=September 16, 2017}}</ref>
=====Seattle, Washington===== On June 5, 2017, Seattle's City Council voted 7-1 to pass a 1.75 cents per ounce tax on sugary drinks; the tax does not include diet soda drinks or fruit drinks and it started on January 1, 2018.<ref>[http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-city-council-says-yes-to-soda-tax/ Seattle City Council says yes to soda tax] Retrieved June 5, 2017</ref> After the tax was implemented, people were surprised that the tax made a case (24 cans) of Coke become $7.35 more expensive when compared to a case of Diet Coke or Coke Zero. The $15 million Seattle assumes will be collected from the tax will be used for programs that give access to more fruits and vegetables for low-income families, adding education programs and studying the tax on how it impacts behavior.<ref>Jan 5, 2018 [http://www.kiro7.com/news/local/sticker-shock-over-seattles-new-sugary-drink-tax/677490924 Sticker shock over Seattle's new sugary drink tax] Retrieved January 23, 2018</ref> Seattle collected $4 million in the first four months of the tax.<ref>[https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-collects-more-than-4m-from-new-tax-on-sugary-beverages/ Seattle collects more than 4m from new tax on sugary beverages] Retrieved May 16, 2018</ref>
==== Scientific studies ==== Coca-Cola has been under fire since 2015 when emails revealed that funding for scientific studies sought to influence research to be more favorable to soda.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/coca-cola-funds-scientists-who-shift-blame-for-obesity-away-from-bad-diets|title=Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets|first=Anahad|last=O’Connor|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> Research funded by soda companies are 34 times more likely to find soda has no significant health impacts on obesity or diabetes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-sugary-drink-research-20161031-story.html|title=Does the soda industry manipulate research on sugary drinks' health effects?|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
Taxing soda can lead to a reduction in overall consumption, according to a scientific study published in the ''[[Archives of Internal Medicine]]'' in March 2010. The study found that a 10 percent tax on soda led to a 7 percent reduction in calories from soft drinks. These researchers believe that an 18 percent tax on these foods could cut daily intake by 56 calories per person, resulting in a weight loss of 5 pounds (2 kg) per person per year. The study followed 5,115 young adults ages 18 to 30 from 1985 to 2006.<ref>Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6275T720100308 Tax Soda, Pizza To Cut Obesity Researchers say], 8 March 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://pubs.ama-assn.org/media/2010a/0308.dtl#1 | title=Unhealthy Foods Become Less Popular With Increasing Costs | publisher=[[American Medical Association]] |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=18 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329092611/http://pubs.ama-assn.org/media/2010a/0308.dtl |archivedate=29 March 2010}}</ref>
A 2010 study published in the medical journal ''[[Health Affairs]]'' found that if taxes were about 18 cents on the dollar, they would make a significant difference in consumption.<ref>[http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/content/full/hlthaff.2009.0061v1 Health Affairs, Soda Taxes, Soft Drink Consumption, And Children's Body Mass Index] 1 April 2010</ref><ref>Associated Press [https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iH4SZwbKI9PYhye5kJT_WLhm4B4AD9EQ1LN01 Study: Small Soda Taxes Don’t Dent Obesity] 1 April 2010, {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404132722/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iH4SZwbKI9PYhye5kJT_WLhm4B4AD9EQ1LN01 |date=4 April 2010 }}</ref>
Research from [[Duke University]] and the [[National University of Singapore]] released in December 2010 tested larger taxes and determined that a 20 percent and 40 percent taxes on sugar-sweetened beverages would largely not affect calorie intake because people switch to untaxed, but equally caloric, beverages. Kelly Brownell, a proponent of soda taxes, reacted by stating that “[t]he fact is that nobody has been able to see how people will really respond under these conditions.”<ref>Park, Alice (13 December 2010) [http://healthland.time.com/2010/12/13/study-sugar-tax-may-lead-to-only-modest-weight-loss "Study: Soda Taxes May Not Be Enough to Curb Obesity"] TIME.</ref> Similarly, a 2010 study concluded that while people would drink less soda as a result of a soda tax, they would also compensate for this reduction by switching to other high-calorie beverages.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047272710001222 | title=The effects of soft drink taxes on child and adolescent consumption and weight outcomes | author=Fletcher, Jason M. | journal=Journal of Public Economics |date=December 2010 | volume=94 | issue=11–12 | pages=967–974 | doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2010.09.005}}</ref> In response to these arguments, the [[American Public Health Association]] released a statement in 2012 in which they argued that "Even if individuals switch to 100% juice or chocolate milk, this would be an improvement, as those beverages contribute some nutrients to the diet."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.apha.org/policies-and-advocacy/public-health-policy-statements/policy-database/2014/07/23/13/59/taxes-on-sugar-sweetened-beverages | title=Taxes on Sugar-Sweetened Beverages: Policy Statement | publisher=APHA | date=30 October 2012 | accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref>
A 2011 study in the journal ''[[Preventive Medicine (journal)|Preventive Medicine]]'' concluded that "a modest tax on sugar-sweetened beverages could both raise significant revenues and improve public health by reducing obesity".<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Andreyeva | first1 = T. | last2 = Chaloupka | first2 = F. J. | last3 = Brownell | first3 = K. D. | doi = 10.1016/j.ypmed.2011.03.013 | title = Estimating the potential of taxes on sugar-sweetened beverages to reduce consumption and generate revenue | journal = Preventive Medicine | volume = 52 | issue = 6 | pages = 413–416 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21443899 | pmc = }}</ref> It has been used by the [[Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity at Yale]] to estimate revenue from a soda tax, depending on the state, year and tax rate.<ref>[http://www.yaleruddcenter.org/sodatax.aspx Revenue Calculator for Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Taxes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507100406/http://www.yaleruddcenter.org/sodatax.aspx |date=7 May 2013 }}</ref>
A 2012 study by [[Y. Claire Wang]], also in the journal ''Health Affairs'', estimates that a penny per ounce tax on sugared beverages could prevent 2.4 million cases of diabetes per year, 8,000 strokes, and 26,000 premature deaths over 10 years.<ref>Allison Aubrey, "Could a Soda Tax Prevent 2,600 Deaths Per Year?" NPR.org, 12 January 2012</ref>
In 2012, just before the city of Richmond began voting on a soda tax, a study was presented at a conference held by the [[American Public Health Association]] regarding the potential effects of such a tax in California. The study concluded that, given that soda's price elasticity is such that taxing it would reduce consumption by 10–20 percent, that this reduction "...is projected to reduce diabetes incidence by 2.9–5.6% and [[Coronary heart disease|CHD]] by 0.6–1.2%."<ref>[https://apha.confex.com/apha/140am/webprogram/Paper265089.html Health benefits, particularly in high risk populations, projected from an excise tax on sugar-sweetened beverages intake in California]</ref>
A 2013 study in the ''[[American Journal of Agricultural Economics]]'' concluded that a 0.5-cent-per-ounce tax on soft drinks would reduce consumption, but "increase sodium and fat intakes as a result of product substitution," in line with the Duke University study mentioned above.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://ajae.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2013/07/28/ajae.aat049.full | title=Predicting the Effects of Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Taxes on Food and Beverage Demand in a Large Demand System | author=Zhen, Chen | journal=American Journal of Agricultural Economics |date=July 2013 | volume=95 | doi=10.1093/ajae/aat049 | pages=1–25| pmc=4022288 }}</ref>
A 2014 study published in the ''American Journal of Public Health'' concluded that Sugar-Sweetened Beverages (SSBs) don’t have a negative impact on employment. Even though job losses in the taxed industry occurred, they were offset by new employment in other sectors of the economy.<ref>Lisa M. Powell, Roy Wada, Joseph J. Persky, Frank J. Chaloupka, “Employment Impact of Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Taxes”, American Journal of Public Health 104, no. 4 (April 1, 2014): pp. 672-677.</ref>
A 2016 modelling study estimated that a 20% tax on SSBs would decrease the consumption of SSBs in Australia by 12.6%. The tax could decline the prevalence of obesity in the Australian population, which could lead to gains in health-adjusted life years. The results showed an increase of 7.6 days in full health for a 20-24-year-old male and a 3.7 day increase in longevity for their female peers.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Veerman | first1 = JL | last2 = Sacks | first2 = G | last3 = Antonopoulos | first3 = N | last4 = Martin | first4 = J | year = 2016 | title = The Impact of a Tax on Sugar-Sweetened Beverages on Health and Health Care Costs: A Modelling Study | url = https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0151460 | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 11 | issue = 4| page = e0151460 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0151460}}</ref>
==== Proposals ==== There have been a number of proposed taxes on sugary beverages, including:
* In 1914, U.S. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] proposed a special revenue tax on soft drinks, beer and [[patent medicine]] after the outbreak of [[World War I]] caused a decline in imports and a corresponding decline in credit created by import [[tariff]]s.<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1914-09-01/ed-1/seq-1/ "Wilson Proposes Soft Drink Tax,"] Hawaiian Gazette. 1 September 1914. Page 1. Retrieved 1 September 2014.</ref> This proposed taxation measure was not however linked to the anticipated health outcomes of reduced sugar sweetened beverage consumption. * In 1994, one of the first instances where the idea of a targeted tax on sugar sweetened drinks with a link to anticipated beneficial health outcomes, was proposed by [[Kelly D. Brownell]], Director of the [[Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity at Yale]]. * In a 2009 "Perspective" piece in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'', Kelly D. Brownell, Director of the Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity at Yale, and [[Thomas R. Frieden]], Director of the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], argue for taxing sugary beverages. The authors propose that sugary beverages may be the single largest cause of the obesity epidemic. They state that an excise tax of one cent per ounce would reduce consumption by more than 10%.<ref name="hartocollis1">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/03/nyregion/03sodatax.html | work=The New York Times | title=Soda Tax in N.Y. a Victim of Industry Campaign | first=Anemona | last=Hartocollis | date=2 July 2010}}</ref> * Maryland and Virginia are two of 33 states that levy sales taxes on soda. Maryland taxes soda at a rate of 6%, while Virginia’s rate is 1.5%. {{citation needed|date=June 2012}} Virginia is also one of six states that impose a state excise tax on soda in addition to a sales tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tax.virginia.gov/content/miscellaneous-taxes|title=Miscellaneous Taxes|publisher=}}</ref> * In 2009, the Obama Administration explored levying an excise tax on sweetened beverages as part of health care reform efforts, but the proposal was abandoned after heavy [[lobbying]] by the beverage industry.<ref>Tom Hamburger and Kim Geiger, [http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/07/nation/la-na-soda-tax7-2010feb07 "Beverage Industry Douses Tax on Soft Drinks."] ''Los Angeles Times'', 7 February 2010.</ref> * In 2010, New York State considered a soda tax, however opposition from the soda industry and economists made a strong antitax campaign, spending at least double of the tax supporters and the plan failed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hartocollis|first1=Anemona |title=Failure of State Soda Tax Plan Reflects Power of an Antitax Message|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/03/nyregion/03sodatax.html|date=July 2, 2010|website=The New York Times}}</ref> * In 2012, the City Council of [[Richmond, California]] placed the soda tax on the November 2012 ballot along with an advisory measure asking voters how they would like to spend the tax revenue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sireweb.ci.richmond.ca.us/sirepub/cache/2/tlmgcs00g42zimnqfdqcb25q/33714608302012030449501.PDF|title=Richmond Municipal Code CHAPTER 7.08 SUGAR-SWEETENED BEVERAGES|publisher=}}</ref> This proposal was rejected by the voters with 67% voting no and 33% voting yes.<ref>{{Citation | title = Voters resoundingly reject Richmond 'soda' tax | url = http://www.mercurynews.com/2012/11/06/voters-resoundingly-reject-richmond-soda-tax/ | date=6 November 2012 | journal = MercuryNews.com | accessdate = 20 March 2017 |last=Rogers |first=Robert}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2012/11/07/soda-tax-trounced-in-richmond-but-may-rise-again-on-larger-stages/ | title=Soda tax trounced in Richmond but may rise again on larger stages | work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] | date=7 November 2012 | accessdate=20 March 2017 | author=Rogers, Robert}}</ref> * In the [[California State Legislature]], soda tax proposals have been introduced several times, but have not passed.<ref name="JWhite">Jeremy B. White, [http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article71436032.html California soda tax bill pulled without a vote], ''Sacramento Bee'' (April 12, 2016).</ref> In 2013, California state senator [[Bill Monning]] proposed a soda tax,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/26/california-soda-tax_n_3165417.html|title=New California Soda-Tax Bill Under Consideration|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> but the bill died in committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/regions/california/article_473ab2d2-c3e2-11e2-881d-0019bb30f31a.html|title=Bill Monning's Proposed Soda Tax Dies in Committee|work=Monterey County Weekly}}</ref> In 2014, a 1-cent-per-ounce statewide soda tax was proposed in the legislature, but was defeated amid opposition by the California Beverage Association, a business lobbying group.<ref name="TryAgain">Patrick McGreevy, [http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-sac-soda-tax-20160308-story.html More expensive soda? Lawmakers want to tax sugary drinks], ''Los Angeles Times'' (March 8, 2016).</ref> In 2016, Assemblymen [[Richard Bloom]] and [[Jim Wood (California politician)|Jim Wood]] introduced a bill to create a "health impact fee" of 2-cent-per-ounce on sugary drinks, with the revenue collected from the tax to go toward programs for making drinking water safe, promoting [[oral health]], and preventing obesity and diabetes.<ref name="TryAgain"/> However, the proposal again faced strong opposition from industry groups, and the bill's proponents withdrew the proposal without a vote after it became clear that it lacked the votes to pass.<ref name="JWhite"/> * In June 2013, the city of [[Telluride, Colorado]] proposed a penny-per-ounce soda tax;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.coprevent.org/2013/06/telluride-proposes-soda-tax.html | title=Telluride proposes soda tax | publisher=Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment | date=26 June 2013 | accessdate=9 August 2013 | author=Brendsel, Dave}}</ref> however, it was rejected in November, with 68% of voters voting against it.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/thespot/2013/11/06/quirky-ballot-issues-bag-fee-in-durango-falls-soda-tax-in-telluride-denied/102393/ | title=Quirky ballot issues: Durango stuffs bag fee, Telluride slams soda tax | work=[[The Denver Post]] | date=6 November 2013 | accessdate=7 November 2013 | author=Meyer, Jeremy}}</ref> * In July 2014, U.S. Representative [[Rosa DeLauro]] of Connecticut, proposed a national soda tax bill in the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/30/opinion/mark-bittman-introducing-the-national-soda-tax.html?_r=0 | title=Introducing the National Soda Tax | work=The New York Times | date=29 July 2014 | accessdate=10 September 2014 | author=Bittman, Mark | authorlink=Mark Bittman}}</ref> * In November 2014, voters in [[San Francisco]] and [[Berkeley, California]] voted on soda tax ballot measures.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bump|first1=Philip|title=How a soda tax fight in San Francisco explains California politics|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2014/10/07/how-a-soda-tax-fight-in-san-francisco-explains-california-politics/|accessdate=24 October 2014|website=The Washington Post|date=7 October 2014}}</ref> The measure was approved in Berkeley<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/City_of_Berkeley_Sugary_Beverages_and_Soda_Tax_Question,_Measure_D_(November_2014) |title=City of Berkeley Sugary Beverages and Soda Tax Question, Measure D (November 2014) |publisher=Ballotpedia |date= |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> and received 55% of the vote in San Francisco, which was short of the needed 2/3 [[supermajority]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/City_of_San_Francisco_Sugary_Drink_Tax,_Proposition_E_(November_2014) |title=City of San Francisco Sugary Drink Tax, Proposition E (November 2014) |publisher=Ballotpedia |date= |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> * In November 2016, [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]] began considering a tax on all sugar-sweetened beverages, including soda, sports drinks, and iced tea, to fund early childhood education.<ref>[https://www.abqjournal.com/887057/mayor-wants-soda-tax-to-support-early-education.html Mayor wants soda tax to support early childhood education] Albuquerque Journal</ref> However, voters rejected the proposal in a May 2017 special election.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.abqjournal.com/997373/early-returns-are-against-sugary-drinks-tax.html |title= Updated: Soda tax goes flat in Santa Fe |author= T.S. Last, Journal staff writer |website= www.abqjournal.com}}</ref>
==== Public support ==== A 2016 poll by Morning Consult-Vox finds Americans split on their support of a soda tax.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://morningconsult.com/alert/poll-americans-split-soda-taxes/|title=Poll: Americans split on soda taxes |date=6 May 2016}}</ref> Attitudes seem to have shifted a lot since 2013 when a poll concluded that "respondents were opposed to government taxes on sugary drinks and candy by a more than 2-to-1 margin."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://health.usnews.com/health-news/news/articles/2013/04/25/most-americans-oppose-soda-candy-taxes|title=Most Americans Oppose Soda, Candy Taxes|work=US News & World Report}}</ref> In California, however, support for a tax has been high for a few years. According to a [[Field Poll]] conducted in 2012, "Nearly 3 out of 5 California voters would support a special fee on soft drinks to fight childhood obesity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/health/article/Poll-shows-support-for-soda-tax-to-fight-obesity-3457423.php|title=Poll shows support for soda tax to fight obesity|work=SFGate}}</ref> Support for a soda tax in New York was higher when pollsters say the money will go towards health care. A Quinnipiac University poll released in April 2010 found that New Yorkers opposed a state tax on soda of one penny per ounce by a 35-point margin, but opposition dropped to a margin of one point when respondents were told the money would go towards health care.<ref>Drake, Bruce. [https://web.archive.org/web/20100415161938/http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/04/14/n/ "Tax Sugary Drinks? New Yorkers Say 'No' but Leave Some Wiggle Room"] Politics Daily. 14 April 2010.</ref> A Thompson Reuters poll released in the same month found that 51 percent of Americans opposed a soda tax, while 33 percent supported one.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2010/04/in_obesity_fight_a_third_of_am.html | work=NPR | title=In Obesity Fight, A Third Of Americans Support Soda Tax | first=Scott | last=Hensley | date=21 April 2010}}</ref>
==== Lobbying ==== Fighting the creation of [[soft drink]] taxes, the [[American Beverage Association]], the largest U.S. trade organization for soft drink bottlers, has spent considerable money lobbying Congress. The Association's annual lobbying spending rose from about $391,000 to more than $690,000 from 2003 to 2008. And, in the 2010 election cycle, its lobbying grew to $8.67 million. These funds helped to pay for 25 lobbyists at seven different lobbying firms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientlbs.php?lname=American+Beverage+Assn&year=2009|title=Lobbying Spending Database-American Beverage Assn, 2009|publisher=[[Center for Responsive Politics]]}}</ref>
An industry group called "Americans Against Food Taxes," backed by juice maker Welch's, soft drink maker PepsiCo Inc, the American Beverage Association, the Corn Refiners Association, McDonald's Corporation and Burger King Holdings Inc used national advertising and conducted lobbying to oppose these taxes.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN16158491 Tax Soft Drinks To Fight Obesity, US experts say] Reuters, 16 September 2009.</ref> The group has characterized the soda tax as a regressive tax, which would unfairly burden the poor<ref>[http://www.nofoodtaxes.com/facts/#education "Education, Not Taxes] Americans Against Food Taxes, 2012</ref>
====Arguments against the sugary drinks tax==== * The criteria on what drinks are taxed may not include equally bad substitutes like fruit juice, energy-dense snacks and biscuits.<ref name="Silano, Marco 2017">Silano, Marco, and Carlo Agostoni. "To Tax Or Not To Tax Sugary Drinks? This Is The Question". Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition (2017): 1. Web.</ref> * The tax is regressive since consumers on lower incomes will be more negatively impacted by higher prices than consumers on higher incomes.<ref name="Silano, Marco 2017"/> This regressive effect of the sugary drinks tax can be counteracted if the collected tax revenue is used to subsidize healthier foods.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brownell | first1 = Kelly D. | last2 = Frieden | first2 = Thomas R. | year = 2009 | title = Ounces Of Prevention — The Public Policy Case For Taxes On Sugared Beverages | url = | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 360 | issue = 18| pages = 1805–1808 | doi=10.1056/nejmp0902392}}</ref> * Cross-border shopping can also be an easy way out for consumers to not pay the tax as they will buy sugary drinks from areas where they are not taxed.<ref name="Silano, Marco 2017"/>
===Various island nations and territories=== Island nations and territories have been successful in passing soda taxes. Just like with [[tobacco taxes]], smaller communities are often the first to pass a new type of tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520222861|title=Tobacco War|publisher=}}</ref>
====Barbados==== Barbados passed a soda tax in September 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barbadostoday.bb/2015/06/15/tax-on-sweet-drinks/|title=Tax on sweet drinks|first=Sandy|last=Deane|date=15 June 2015|publisher=}}</ref> applied as an excise of 10%.
====Fiji==== Fiji has an import tax and an excise tax on soda.<ref name="heapro.oxfordjournals.org">{{cite journal|url=http://heapro.oxfordjournals.org/content/26/1/55|title=Taxing soft drinks in the Pacific: implementation lessons for improving health|first1=Anne Marie|last1=Thow|first2=Christine|last2=Quested|first3=Lisa|last3=Juventin|first4=Russ|last4=Kun|first5=A. Nisha|last5=Khan|first6=Boyd|last6=Swinburn|date=1 March 2011|publisher=|journal=Health Promot. Int.|volume=26|issue=1|pages=55–64|via=heapro.oxfordjournals.org|doi=10.1093/heapro/daq057|pmid=20739326}}</ref>
====French Polynesia==== French Polynesia implemented taxes on soft drinks in 2002.<ref name="heapro.oxfordjournals.org"/>
====Mauritius==== Mauritius passed a soda tax in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://psmag.com/a-world-tour-of-sugary-taxes-c6ffe2b3b225#.a8vejhu45|title=A World Tour of Sugary Taxes|first=Francie|last=Diep|date=13 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
====Nauru==== Nauru implemented a soda tax in 2007.<ref name="heapro.oxfordjournals.org"/>
====Samoa==== Samoa passed a soda tax in 1984.<ref name="heapro.oxfordjournals.org"/>
==== St Helena ==== In March 2014, the government of the island of [[St Helena]], a [[British Overseas Territory]] in the South Atlantic, announced that it would be introducing an additional import duty of 75 pence per litre on sugar-sweetened carbonated drinks with more than 15 grams of sugar per litre.<ref name="St Helena Government 2014 Budget">{{cite news|last=St Helena Government|title=Budget Speech 2014|url=http://www.sainthelena.gov.sh/budget-speech-201415|date=21 March 2014|accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> The measure was introduced in May 2014 as part of a number of measures to tackle obesity on the island and the resulting high incidence of type 2 diabetes.
====Tonga==== Tonga has a soda tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foodresearch.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Food-and-beverages-taxes-final-20-May-2015.pdf|title=Health-related Taxes on Food and Beverages|publisher=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Meat tax]] * [[Fat tax]] * [[Tobacco tax]] * [[Pigovian tax]] * [[Sin Tax]] * [[Liquid Candy]] * [[List of countries by Body Mass Index (BMI)]] * [[Sugary Drinks Portion Cap Rule]]

Save Gov. Paterson's Tax on Sugar Soda'']: Op-Ed in the ''New York Daily News'', by [[Kelly Brownell]] * [https://archive.is/20130725135201/http://yaleruddcenter.org/rudd-report-on-sugar-sweetened-beverage-taxes-an-updated-policy-brief ''Rudd Report on Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Taxes: An Updated Policy Brief'']: by the [[Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity at Yale]]

{{Refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox university | name = Tairunnessa Memorial Medical College | native_name = তাইরুন্নেসা মেমোরিয়াল মেডিকেল কলেজ | native_name_lang = bn | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | other_name = <!-- or: | other_names = --> | former_name = <!-- or: | former_names = --> | established = {{start date|2002}} | type = [[Private university|Private]] [[medical school]] | academic_affiliation = [[University of Dhaka]] | chairman = Jahanara Hoque | principal = Dr Abdul khaleq akond | academic_staff = 143 | administrative_staff = | students = 700 | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | city = Konia | state = [[Gazipur Sadar Upazila]], [[Gazipur District]] | country = [[Bangladesh]] | coor = {{Coord|23.9303|N|90.3888|E|region:BD_type:edu|display=inline,title}} | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | language = English | website = {{URL|tmmch.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Tairunnessa Memorial Medical College''' ('''TMMC''')<ref>http://tmmch.com/</ref> ({{lang-bn|তাইরুন্নেসা মেমোরিয়াল মেডিকেল কলেজ}}) is a [[Private university|private]] [[medical school]] in [[Bangladesh]], established in 1995. It is an institution of the [[Tairunnessa Memorial Medical Centre]]. It was founded by [[M. Shamsul Hoque]], named after his mother, the late [[Tairunnessa]], a social reformer. There is a girls' school in her name in Balaganj as well.
It offers a five-year course of study leading to a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS) degree. A one-year [[internship]] after [[graduation]] is compulsory for all graduates. The degree is recognised by the [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]].
M Shamsul Hoque was born in January 1943 in [[Hamidpur]] of [[Rajnagar Upazila]] in [[Moulovibazar]] which was then part of greater [[Sylhet]]. He helped the religious minorities to flee the country with a small ship he owned. As a result, he was wanted by the Pakistani army in 1971. He established a School named [[Tairunnessa Girls' High School]] in [[Balaganj]] in 1977.
Tairunnessa Memorial Medical Center started as a small [[outpatient]] department at [[Konya]], [[Gazipur District]] in 1995 which over the years has turned into a hospital and research center; TMMC Hospital, a 500-bed hospital complex, a 9 storied college building and an administrative block, a ladies' hostel. It is now one of the renowned Medical colleges in [[Dhaka]] with all departments.
Tairunnessa Memorial Medical College is listed in the [[World Directory of Medical Schools]],<ref>https://search.wdoms.org/home/SchoolDetail/F0002433</ref> published by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) and now maintained as the Avicenna Directory for Medicine and also listed in the [[International Medical Education Directory]] (IMED).<ref>https://imed.faimer.org/results.asp?country=160&school=Tairunnessa+memorial+medical+college&currpage=1&cname=BANGLADESH&city=Gazipur&region=AS&rname=Asia&psize=25</ref> IMED (International Medical Education Directory) recognition allow TMMC medical students/ graduates to apply for USMLE examination by ECFMG,<ref>http://www.usmle.org/bulletin/eligibility/</ref> USA for employment and for post-graduate training in the United States and Canada as well as can apply for PLAB,<ref>http://www.gmc-uk.org/doctors/registration_applications/acceptable_primary_medical_qualification.asp</ref> AMC<ref>http://www.medicalboard.gov.au/Registration/International-Medical-Graduates.aspx</ref> and NZREX<ref>https://www.mcnz.org.nz/get-registered/how-to-register/acceptable-primary-medical-qualifications/</ref> examinations etc. Also Graduates of TMMC are eligible for limited registration with the General Medical Council of United Kingdom.
A Nursing institute was formed in 2008, awarding a B.S.C nursing degree.<ref>http://www.bnmc.gov.bd/Number_of_Institution_with_Seat_Capacity</ref> This became a unit of Tairunnessa Memorial Medical College in 2013.
The TMMC has around 600 students, including students from Nepal and India. The hospital has expanded to 500-beds, and provides a 24-hour emergency service, with additional trauma center, EPI etc. 255 MBBS doctors have passed till 2014 December.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2018}} The Mines Rescue Rules, 1985<ref>[http://www.dgms.net/Mines%20Rescue%20Rules.pdf], [http://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/natlex4.detail?p_lang=en&p_isn=78693]</ref> came into force with effect from 2 April 1985 in [[India]], replacing the previous Coal Mines Rescue Rules-1959, to provide for rescue of work persons in the event of explosion, fire etc. in the Mines.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mines Rescue Rules – 1985 |url=http://www.novamining.com/knowledgebase/indian-mining-regulations/director-general-of-mines-safety/legislation/mines-rescue-rules-1985/ |title=Mines Rescue Rules – 1985 |publisher=Nova Mining |date= |accessdate=2016-11-28}}</ref>
These rules apply to coal and metalliferous underground mines to provide for the establishment of rescue stations and conduct of rescue work. In case of explosion or fire, an inrush of water or influx of gases, services of specially trained men with special rescue apparatuses are required. ==Salient Features<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/natlex4.detail?p_lang=en&p_isn=78693 |title=India - Mines Rescue Rules 1985 |publisher=Ilo.org |date=1952-03-15 |accessdate=2016-11-28}}</ref>== Chapter I - Preliminary
Chapter II - Rescue Stations and Rescue Rooms
Chapter III - Duties and Responsibilities of Superintendents etc.
Chapter IV - Organisation and Equipment in Mines
Chapter V - Conduct of Rescue Work

{{EngvarB|date=November 2013}} {{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = Time to Change | image = File:Time_to_change.png | type = Charitable organisation | founded_date = 2007 | tax_id = | registration_id = | location = 15–19 Broadway, London | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = | area_served = England | product = | mission = To reduce stigma and discrimination | focus = [[Mental illness]] | method = | revenue = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | non-profit_slogan = "Let's end mental health discrimination" | former name = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.time-to-change.org.uk/}} | footnotes = }} '''''Time to Change''''' is a mental health campaign in [[England]], launched in 2007 with the objective of reducing mental health-related stigma and discrimination.
==Description== ''Time to Change'' (TTC) was formed in 2007<ref>[https://www.time-to-change.org.uk/about-us/what-is-time-to-change Who we are], Time to Change. Retrieved 24 March 2018.</ref> by mental health charities [[Mind (charity)|MIND]] and [[Rethink Mental Illness]], aiming to reduce mental health-related stigma and discrimination. A specific objective was to reduce stigma and discrimination by 5 per cent in the first 12 months. The first four years were funded by grants of £20.5 million from the [[Big Lottery Fund]] and [[Comic Relief]].<ref name="PS one year outcomes" />
TTC also asks organisations and individuals to sign a pledge supporting its anti-stigma programme. Organisations signing the pledge include the [[Bank of England]], the [[Financial Conduct Authority]], [[British Gas]], [[British Telecom]], [[Lloyds Banking Group]], [[Ernst & Young]], [[E.ON]], [[PepsiCo]] and parts of the National Health Service.<ref name="Huddersfield MP" /> A pledge event took place at the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] in October 2013, giving MPs an opportunity to sign up.<ref name="Huddersfield MP" />
In 2011, TTC launched a four-week television advertising campaign to promote its new slogan: "It's time to talk. It's Time to Change."<ref>{{cite news |last=Baker |first=Rosie |title=Time to Change attempts to end mental health stigma |work=[[Marketing Week]] |date=22 March 2011 |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/time-to-change-attempts-to-end-mental-health-stigma/3024681.article |accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref>
The campaign has been fronted by a number of celebrities, including political strategist [[Alastair Campbell]], presenter [[Davina McCall]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Campaign to get dads fighting mental health taboo |work=[[Cambridge News]] |date=18 August 2011 |url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Health/Wellbeing-and-fitness/Campaign-to-get-Dads-fighting-mental-health-taboo.htm |accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> singer [[Frankie Sandford]], and boxer [[Ricky Hatton]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Baker |first=Rosie |title=Frankie Sandford fronts new mental health campaign |work=[[Hertfordshire Mercury]] |date=20 August 2013 |url=http://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/Health/Wellbeing-and-fitness/Frankie-Sandford-fronts-new-mental-health-campaign-20130820113137.htm |accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> In 2014, the campaign supported the "Laughing for a Change" project run by actress [[Janice Connolly]], which aimed to promote awareness of mental health through a stand-up comedy tour.<ref>{{cite news |first=Becca |last=Gill |url=http://www.gigglebeats.co.uk/2014/03/review-laughing-for-a-change-the-stand-newcastle/ |title=Review: Laughing for a Change – The Stand, Newcastle |work=Giggle Beats|date=1 March 2014 |accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
==Outcomes== An academic study was carried out to measure whether TTC had met their 5 per cent target in the first 12 months. Though the participation in the telephone surveys was very low, they measured "progress toward meeting TTC's target of a 5 per cent reduction in discrimination".<ref name="PS one year outcomes" />
An independent evaluation of the campaign's first four years took place in 2013. Though it found a reduction in discrimination from friends and families, change in attitudes from health professionals was negligible.<ref>{{cite news|author=David Brindle |title = Mental health anti-stigma campaign fails to shift health professionals' attitudes |work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=|date=3 April 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2013/apr/03/mental-health-anti-stigma-campaign |format=|doi=|accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref>
==Wales== In [[Wales]] the campaign was launched in 2012 under the name ''Time to Change Wales'',<ref name="Health Minister launches ">{{cite news|author=Scott Buckler |title = Health Minister launches campaign to end mental health discrimination in Wales |work=Govtoday |publisher=|date=21 February 2012 |url=http://www.govtoday.co.uk/mental-health/10157-health-minister-launches-campaign-to-end-mental-health-discrimination-in-wales |accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> led by Welsh mental health charities MIND Cymru, [[Gofal]] and [[Hafal]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Julia McWatt |title = Charities want better understanding of mental health in Wales' workplaces |work=[[WalesOnline]] |publisher=Media Wales |date=9 August 2012 |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/charities-want-better-understanding-mental-2025463 |accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref>

Three '''water towers in Września''' once supplied water in [[Września]], Poland. Two [[water tower]]s are still in use.
== Tower on the premises of the water treatment plant ==
The tallest was built in 1904 (some sources say 1907 and 1911) and is the highest building in the vicinity.<ref>{{cite web | title = Gmina Września - Zabytki | url =http://wrzesnia.powiat.pl/turystyka/zabytki/gmina-wrzesnia.html | accessdate = 20 April 2014 }}</ref> The tower is {{convert|64|m}} tall and its top is finished with an interesting brass{{fact|reason=Brass is unheard of for roofing - [[copper]] is much more likely.|date=March 2018}} [[dome]]. The building belongs to the municipal Water Supply and Sewerage Enterprise. Next to the water tower stands the water treatment plant. The tower is near two ponds, allotment gardens and Polytechnic School.
<gallery> File:Wieża ciśnień PWiK 5.JPG|Water tower seen with the surroundings and pond File:Wieża ciśnień PWiK 4.JPG|Brass dome of the water tower </gallery>
== Tower on the railroad station ==
Another tower, built in 1907 and now unused, is located at the [[Września railway station]], near several apartment buildings and an overpass. Another, smaller tower has been destroyed during the bombing on 5 October 1939.
<gallery> File:Wieża ciśnień Września.jpg|Water tower on the railway station File:Września wieża ciśnień (2) WK13.jpg </gallery>
== Extinct tower in the barracks compound ==
A former tower was located in the prussian [[Barracks Complex in Września]]. It did not survive the Russian invasion. The location houses a cinema, a club and Wielkopolska Insurgents’ Trade School No 2.

'''Zygoma implants''' (or '''Zygomatic implants''') are different from conventional dental implants in that they anchor in to the zygomatic bone (cheek bone) rather than the maxilla (upper jaw). They may be used when maxillary bone quality or quantity is inadequate for the placement of regular [[dental implant]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Aparicio|first1=Carlos Ed|title=Zygomatic Implants: The Anatomy-guided Approach|publisher=Quintessence, 2012|pages=268 pages|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=v2p7twAACAAJ&dq=zygoma+implants&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y}}</ref> Inadequate maxillary bone volume may be due to [[bone resorption]] as well as to [[Skeletal pneumaticity|pneumatization]] of the [[maxillary sinus]] or to a combination of both.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Use of zygomatic implants to deal with resorbed posterior maxillae|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.0906-6713.2002.03307.x/abstract|journal = Periodontology 2000|date = 2003-10-01|issn = 1600-0757|pages = 82–89|volume = 33|issue = 1|doi = 10.1046/j.0906-6713.2002.03307.x|language = en|first = Chantal|last = Malevez|first2 = Philippe|last2 = Daelemans|first3 = Philippe|last3 = Adriaenssens|first4 = Françoise|last4 = Durdu}}</ref> The minimal bone height for a standard implant placement in the posterior region of the upper jaw should be about 10 mm to ensure acceptable implant survival.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Maxillary sinus floor elevation: a valuable pre-prosthetic procedure|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1600-0757.1998.tb00133.x/abstract|journal = Periodontology 2000|date = 1998-06-01|issn = 1600-0757|pages = 176–182|volume = 17|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0757.1998.tb00133.x|language = en|first = Chris M.|last = ten Bruggenkate|first2 = Johan P. A.|last2 = van den Bergh}}</ref> When there is inadequate bone available, [[bone grafting]] procedures and [[Sinus lift|sinus lift procedure]]<nowiki/>s may be carried out to increase the volume of bone.Bone grafting procedures in the jaws have the disadvantage of prolonged treatment time, restriction of denture wear, morbidity of the donor surgical site and [[graft rejection]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Davo|first1=Ruben|last2=Malevez|first2=Chantal|last3=Rojas|first3=Juliana|title=Immediate function in the atrophic maxilla using zygoma implants: A preliminary study|journal=The Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry|date=2007|volume=97|pages=S44-S51}}</ref>
Zygoma implants were first introduced in late 1990s by Dr. [[Per-Ingvar Brånemark|Per Ingvar Branemark]] widely acknowledged as the "Father of Dental Implantology". Zygomatic implants have been used for dental rehabilitation in patients with insufficient bone in the posterior upper jaw, due to, for example, [[Ageing|aging]], [[Neoplasm|tumor resection]], trauma, or atrophy. Zygoma implants take the anchorage from the Zygoma/ [[zygomatic bone]] (cheek bone).The Zygomatic bone is denser in quality and more cortical in nature than posterior maxillary bone .<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kato|first1=Yorihisa|last2=Kizu|first2=Yasuhiro|last3=Tonogi|first3=Morio|title=Internal Structure of Zygomatic Bone Related to Zygomatic Fixture|journal=J Oral Maxillofac Surg|date=2005|volume=63|pages=1325–1329}}</ref> Because of the sturdy anchorage achievable in the dense bone of the zygomatic region, and the wide stress distribution achieved on these tilted implants, a prosthesis can often be immediately placed at the time of surgery .<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maló|first1=Paulo|last2=Araujo Nobre|first2=Miguel de|last3=Lopes|first3=Isabel|title=A new approach to rehabilitate the severely atrophic maxilla using extramaxillary anchored implants in immediate function: A pilot study|journal=The Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry|date=2008|volume=100|pages=354–356}}</ref> The Zygoma implant is available in lengths ranging from 30 to 52.5 mm. The head of the zygoma implant is engineered to allow prosthesis attachment at a 45-degree angle to the long axis of the implant.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kreissl|first1=Marion|last2=Heydecke|first2=Guido|last3=Metzger|first3=Marc C|last4=Schoen|first4=Ralf|title=Zygoma implant-supported prosthetic rehabilitation after partial maxillectomy using surgical navigation: A clinical report|journal=The journal of prosthetic dentistry|date=2007|volume=97|pages=121–8}}</ref> Zygomatic implants can be used in patients who do not have any teeth in the upper jaw, patients who have heavily broken down teeth or very mobile teeth due to diseases such as [[Periodontitis|generalised aggressive periodontitis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rajan|first1=Gunaseelan|last2=Baig|first2=Mirza Rustum|last3=Nesan|first3=John|last4=Subramanian|first4=Jayaram|title=Fixed rehabilitation of patient with aggressive periodontitis using zygoma implants|journal=Indian J Dent Res|date=2010|volume=21}}</ref> The success rate of zygomatic implants reported in the literature world-wide is 97 - 98%.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kahnberg|first1=Karl-Erik|last2=Henry|first2=Patric J.|last3=Hirsch|first3=Jan-Mikael|last4=Öhrnell|first4=Lars-Olov|last5=Andreasson|first5=Lars|last6=Brånemark|first6=Per-Ingvar|title=Clinical Evaluation of the Zygoma Implant: 3-Year Follow-Up at 16 Clinics|journal=J Oral Maxillofac Surg|date=2007|volume=65}}</ref> The complications associated with these implants are [[sinusitis]], [[paresthesia]] in the cheek region and oro-antral fistula.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Davó|first1=Rubén|last2=Malevez|first2=Chantal|last3=López-Orellana|first3=Cristóbal|last4=Pastor-Beviá|first4=Francisco|last5=Rojas|first5=Juliana|title=Sinus reactions to immediately loaded zygoma implants: a clinical and radiological study|journal=Eur J Oral Implantol|date=2008|volume=1|issue=1|pages=53–60}}</ref>
